Larned v. Pullman Co., 274 Mass. 201 (19.proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343, 343A; Larned v. Pullman Co., 274 Mass. 201 (1931); and cases discussed below.
Larned v. Pullman Co., 274 Mass. 201 (19.case_name: New England Oil Refining Co. v. Canada Mexico Oil Co.
Larned v. Pullman Co., 274 Mass. 201 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition relates to Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343 and 343A, which concern landowner/possessor liability to invitees for dangerous conditions on land. Larned v. Pullman Co. is an equity/creditors’ bill case about receivership, trust administration, and reaching and applying assets; it does not address premises liability, duties of possessors of land, or any tort standards comparable to §§ 343 or 343A. Therefore, it does not provide authority for that tort proposition and appears to be an inapposite citation.
Larned v. Pullman Co., 274 Mass. 201 (19.relevant_excerpt: The present suit was brought under G. L. c. 214, § 3, cl. 7, whereby are authorized “Suits by creditors to reach and apply, in payment of a debt, any property, right, title or interest, legal or equitable, of a debtor, within or without the commonwealth, which cannot be reached to be attached or taken on execution in an action at law.” Whatever relief is appropriate under general principles of equity is within the scope of such a bill.

Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174.raw_text: Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980)
Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174.proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (landowner’s duty to keep premises safe); Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980) (addressing duty of property owner); see also Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (1994) (discussing duties of landowners and common-law obligations).

Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (19.proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (landowner’s duty to keep premises safe); Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980) (addressing duty of property owner); see also Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (1994) (discussing duties of landowners and common-law obligations).
Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (19.support_reasoning: This decision is a bar discipline opinion concerning attorney misconduct, fees, false statements, and vexatious litigation. It does not discuss premises liability, Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, or the duties of landowners as property owners. Any citation to this case for “duties of landowners and common-law obligations” is therefore inaccurate in this context.
Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (19.relevant_excerpt: This bar discipline appeal arises from an order entered by a single justice of this court suspending Albert G. Tobin (respondent) from the practice of law in the Commonwealth for eighteen months. The order stemmed from three matters contained in two petitions for discipline filed with the Board of Bar Overseers (board) by bar counsel.... [T]he respondent exceeded the bounds of zealous advocacy and his conduct was vexatious and harassing to the courts and opposing litigants.

Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991).proposition: See Prosser & Keeton on Torts; see also Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 282, 343; Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991).
Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991).support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is simply a string of secondary-source citations (Prosser & Keeton; Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 282, 343) with Waters v. Boston appended, implying Waters is tort authority consistent with those negligence/landowner duty standards. The provided opinion, however, is a criminal sentencing/cooperation case that does not concern tort law, negligence definitions, or Restatement §§ 282 or 343. It offers no discussion of Prosser & Keeton, the Restatement, or tort principles, so it does not support that tort proposition.
Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “Even if, in a contractual sense, there was no enforceable obligation to make an ‘on the street’ recommendation, the question of fairness in the Commonwealth’s treatment of the defendant is involved in this case. See Commonwealth v. Smith, 384 Mass. 519, 522 (1981) (even where no contract exists, principles of fundamental fairness must be considered)… If representatives of the district attorney’s office permitted the defendant reasonably to believe that his successful cooperation… fairness obliges the Commonwealth to make the sought-after sentencing recommendation.”

Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (.raw_text: Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982)
Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (.proposition: Massachusetts cases have addressed landowner liability for hazardous snow and ice conditions and the duty to take reasonable measures to protect entrants and invitees. See, e.g., Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980); Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982).
Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982), as provided, is a domestic relations case concerning divorce, alimony, property division under G.L. c. 208, § 34, counsel fees, and separate support arrearages. It does not address premises liability, landowner duties, or hazardous snow and ice conditions. Therefore it does not support the cited proposition regarding landowner liability for snow and ice hazards and the duty to protect entrants or invitees.
Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 34, empowers the courts to make an equitable division of property incident to a divorce proceeding. The court must set out and consider all the mandatory factors enumerated in the statute when making its award… Once the judge has weighed all the considerations, he must use his discretion in awarding alimony or assigning estate assets.”

Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (.proposition: See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute); see also Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (2000) (discussing comparative negligence), and accompanying jurisprudence.
Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (.case_name: Annese Electrical Services, Inc. v. City of Newton
Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (.support_reasoning: The proposition claims Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (2000), discusses comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85, but the text provided is actually from a different case (a public bidding dispute between Annese Electrical Services and the city of Newton, involving G.L. c. 149, §§ 44A–44H). This opinion does not concern tort law, negligence, or comparative negligence, nor does it mention G.L. c. 231, § 85. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the cited comparative negligence proposition.
Coffin v. Bowater, Inc., 431 Mass. 765 (.relevant_excerpt: "General Laws c. 149, §§ 44A-44H, is known as the competitive bidding statute. It provides comprehensive and detailed requirements for public agencies that award building contracts estimated to cost more than $25,000. G. L. c. 149, § 44A (2)."

Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981.proposition: See, e.g., Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981); Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968) (landowner liability for dangerous conditions on premises), and Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 duty and notice doctrines.
Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981.case_name: Globe Newspaper Co. v. Superior Court
Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981.support_reasoning: This opinion deals entirely with First Amendment public and press access to criminal trials and the constitutionality of mandatory courtroom closure under a Massachusetts statute. It does not involve premises liability, duties of landowners, dangerous conditions on property, or Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 notice/duty doctrines. Citing Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981), for landowner liability principles is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s subject matter or holding.
Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981.relevant_excerpt: “In Richmond Newspapers, the Supreme Court recognized for the first time that the First Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees a right of public access to criminal trials. We hold that G. L. c. 278, § 16A, as construed in Globe I, is constitutional under the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution.”

Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353.raw_text: Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968)
Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353.proposition: See, e.g., Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981); Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968) (landowner liability for dangerous conditions on premises), and Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 duty and notice doctrines.
Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353.support_reasoning: The opinion is a dram shop / negligent sale of alcohol case focused on statutory violations and proximate cause, not on landowner or premises‑liability principles under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343. It does not discuss a landowner’s duty regarding dangerous conditions on premises or notice doctrines; instead, it analyzes whether illegally serving alcohol to a minor was a proximate cause of injuries occurring off the premises. Thus it does not support the proposition about landowner liability for dangerous conditions on premises or § 343 duty and notice doctrines.
Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353.relevant_excerpt: "That the defendant could have been found to have sold beer to minors who became intoxicated would not, without more, satisfy the burden upon the plaintiffs to prove proximate cause. Sullivan v. Griffin, 318 Mass. 359, 361-362. Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 664. See Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3; Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434-435. See also Kelly v. Hathaway Bakeries, Inc. 312 Mass. 297, 299; Shaw v. Boston Am. League Baseball Co. 325 Mass. 419, 423-424."

Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (1994); Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982); Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981); Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980); Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968); Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991); Beaulieu v. Board of Health (as instructive on notice and municipal/owner responsibilities); Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 258 (1993); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (1980); and other authorities recognizing landowner liabilities in similar circumstances.

Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35.raw_text: Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 258 (1993)
Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35.proposition: Additional Massachusetts cases addressing landowner and occupier liability for dangerous conditions and slip-and-fall incidents include but are not limited to: Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (1994); Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982); Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981); Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980); Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968); Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991); Beaulieu v. Board of Health (as instructive on notice and municipal/owner responsibilities); Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 258 (1993); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (1980); and other authorities recognizing landowner liabilities in similar circumstances.
Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35.support_reasoning: This case concerns allocation of attorney’s fees between a workers’ compensation insurer’s counsel and the employee’s counsel under G.L. c. 152, § 15, after a third‑party settlement. It does not analyze duties of landowners or occupiers, premises liability, or slip‑and‑fall standards; the underlying injury is only background and no liability rules for landowners are discussed or decided. Therefore, it does not provide authority on landowner/occupier liability for dangerous conditions or slip‑and‑fall incidents.
Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35.relevant_excerpt: “Pinto was hurt on July 7, 1988 (a fracture of the radial head of his right elbow) when he fell from one floor to another at a project in which Aberthaw Construction Company was the general contractor… Under the settlement agreement approved by the court, USF&G was to be reimbursed $88,000 for its workers’ compensation lien… There remains the question of the appropriate apportionment of the $29,000 set aside when negotiations between the firms foundered.”

Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (.proposition: Additional Massachusetts cases addressing landowner and occupier liability for dangerous conditions and slip-and-fall incidents include but are not limited to: Fiandaca v. Cunningham, 417 Mass. 94 (1994); Draper v. Boston Gas Co., 385 Mass. 37 (1982); Carter v. Fitchburg, 383 Mass. 847 (1981); Sweeney v. Dowling, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 174 (1980); Norton v. A. & P. Food Stores, Inc., 353 Mass. 501 (1968); Waters v. Boston, 409 Mass. 543 (1991); Beaulieu v. Board of Health (as instructive on notice and municipal/owner responsibilities); Brancaccio v. National Shawmut Bank, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 258 (1993); Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (1980); and other authorities recognizing landowner liabilities in similar circumstances.
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (.support_reasoning: The proposition groups Foley v. Polaroid as an example of Massachusetts law on landowner/occupier liability and slip-and-fall or dangerous-condition cases. Foley, however, concerns the exclusivity of the Workers’ Compensation Act as to an employee’s claims for emotional distress, defamation, malicious prosecution, civil rights violations, and loss of consortium arising from workplace events. It does not address premises liability, dangerous property conditions, or slip-and-fall incidents, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 545 (.relevant_excerpt: "We now consider each of the plaintiffs’ claims separately to determine whether relief is sought for injury which would be compensable under the act as a ‘personal injury arising out of and in the course of . . . employment.’ G. L. c. 152, § 26. With respect to the claim for intentional infliction of mental distress, the employee recognizes that in Fitzgibbons’s Case, 374 Mass. 633 (1978), we held that emotional distress arising out of employment was a personal injury under the act."
